{{For|the village in Afghanistan|Dahan-e Khawal}} [[File:Egypte – Haywal. (Danseur excentrique habillé en danseuse).jpg|thumb|200px|Postcard depicting a khawal (pre–1907).]] The '''''khawal''''' (plural ''khawalat'') ar: خول was traditional 1911 native [[Egypt]]ian male dancer [[cross-dressing|cross-dressed]] in feminine attire and was popular up until the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. ==Name== In the oldest Arabic dictionary ''[[Kitab al-'Ayn]]'' the definition of ''khawal'' was a "servant" or "slave". ''Khawalat'' were acquired by unknown means, perhaps purchased as the spoils of war. However, they were different from classic slaves because the term did not necessarily imply ownership.{{cite book|author=Mohammed Ennaji|date=2013|title=Slavery, the State, and Islam|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=182|isbn=}} ==History== In response to the prohibition of women dancing in public, cross-dressing males took their place. The khawal were [[effeminate]] male transvestite dancers in Egypt that emulated the female [[ghawazi]] by dancing with [[castanets|castanet]] self accompaniment, their hands painted with [[henna]], long hair dressed in braids, plucking facial hair, wearing make-up, and adopting the manners of women.
As they impersonate women, their dances are exactly of the same description as those of the Ghawazee [female dancers] ... Their general appearance ... is more feminine than masculine: they suffer the hair of the head to grow long, and generally braid it, in the manner of women ... they imitate the women also in applying [[Kohl (cosmetics)|kohl]] and henna to their eyes and hands like women. In the streets, when not engaged in dancing, they often veil their faces; not from shame, but merely to affect the manners of women.{{cite book|author=Joseph A. Boone|date=2014|title=The Homoerotics of Orientalism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N3QRAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA188|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=9780231521826|page=188}}
They would distinguish themselves from real females by wearing a costume that was part male and part female.{{cite book|author=Judith Lynne Hanna|date=1988|title=Dance, Sex, and Gender: Signs of Identity, Dominance, Defiance, and Desire|url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0226315517|publisher=University of Chicago Press|pages=57–58|isbn=9780226315515}} The khawal performed at various functions such as weddings,{{cite book|author=Edward William Lane|date=1842|title=An Account of the Manners and Customs of the Modern Egyptians|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HSlDAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA260|volume=1|publisher=London: Charles Knight & Co.|page=260}} births, [[circumcision]]s, and festivals.{{cite book|editor=edited by Mona L. Russell Ph.D.|date=2013|title=Middle East in Focus: Egypt|url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=159884234X|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781598842340|page=335}} They also performed for foreign visitors in the nineteenth century sometimes causing confusion among the spectators.{{cite book|author=Karin van Nieuwkerk|date=2010|title=A Trade like Any Other: Female Singers and Dancers in Egypt|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eEure7RawoAC&pg=PA33|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=9780292786806|page=33}} The khawal were perceived as sexually available; their male audiences found their ambiguity seductive.{{cite book|author=Anthony Shay|date=2014|title=The Dangerous Lives of Public Performers: Dancing, Sex, and Entertainment in the Islamic World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BO1CBAAAQBAJ&pg|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=9781137432384|page=160}} In modern Egyptian slang, the term is derogatory and refers to a [[Top, bottom and versatile#Bottom|passive gay man]].{{cite book|author=Human Rights Watch|date=2004|title=In a Time of Torture: The Assault on Justice in Egypt's Crackdown on Homosexual Conduct|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L-lEfP5F6B0C&pg=PA6|publisher=|isbn=1564322963|page=6}} ==See also== * [[Köçek]] * [[Bacha bazi]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Egyptian culture]] [[Category:Egyptian male dancers|*]] [[Category:Transgender in Asia]] [[Category:Middle Eastern culture]] [[Category:Arab culture]] [[Category:Belly dance]] [[Category:Male erotic dancers]] [[Category:Cross-dressing]] [[Category:LGBT in Egypt]] [[Category:18th century in LGBT history]] [[Category:19th century in LGBT history]]

{{Use Australian English|date=May 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date= May 2015}} {{Infobox cave | name = Koonalda Cave | other_name = | photo = | photo_width = | photo_caption = | map = South Australia | map_width = | map_caption = | map_alt = | location = [[Nullarbor, South Australia]] | coords = {{coord|31.406866|S| 129.836129|E|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = {{cite web|title=Search result for 'Koonalda Cave' with the following datasets selected - 'Suburbs and localities' and 'Gazetteer'|url=http://location.sa.gov.au/viewer/|website=Location SA Map viewer|publisher=Government of South Australia|accessdate=16 January 2018}} | land_registry_number = | grid_ref_UK = | grid_ref_Ireland = | grid_ref = | depth = | length = | height_variation = | elevation = | discovery = 1935 | geology = | entrance_count = | entrance_list = | difficulty = | hazards = | access = | show_cave = | show_cave_length = | lighting = | visitors = | features = | survey = | survey_format = | website = }} '''Koonalda Cave''' is a [[cave]] in the Australian state of [[South Australia]], on the [[Nullarbor Plain]] in the locality of [[Nullarbor, South Australia|Nullarbor]]. It is notable as an [[archeological site]].[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/321989/Koonalda-Cave "Koonalda Cave"], ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]][http://austhrutime.com/koonalda_cave.htm "Koonalda Cave"] ''Australia Thru Time''. Retrieved 2014-3-17. I.D. Lewis described the cave in 1976 as:
Large doline 60m in diam. and 25m deep; talus slope to two main large passages connected by a high window; total length of cave 1200m; three lakes at -80m; narrow airspace beyond third lake leads to 45m diam. dome and lake; another 30m sump leads off this...
Thousands of square metres in the cave are covered in parallel finger-marked geometric lines and patterns, [[Indigenous Australian]] artwork which has been dated as 20,000 years old,[http://www.mnsu.edu/emuseum/archaeology/sites/pacific/koonalda.html "Koonalda"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080609030320/http://www.mnsu.edu/emuseum/archaeology/sites/pacific/koonalda.html |date=9 June 2008 }}, [[Minnesota State University, Mankato|Minnesota State University]] making it older than any known [[prehistoric art]] in Europe.[[Geoffrey Blainey|BLAINEY, Geoffrey]], ''Triumph of the Nomads: A History of Aboriginal Australia'', 1976, {{ISBN|0-87951-084-6}}, p.84 It is located about {{convert|99|km}} west of the [[Nullarbor, South Australia| Nullarbor roadhouse]] and about {{convert|60|mi|km|0|order=flip}} north east from [[Eucla, Western Australia|Eucla]] within the [[Nullarbor Wilderness Protection Area]].{{cite web|title=Protected Areas of South Australia September (Map) 2014 Edition|url=http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/bf6977cb-f1f9-4700-9b5f-a35500fda94f/protected-areas-of-south-australia-map.pdf|publisher=Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources|accessdate=15 April 2015}} The cave was abandoned 19,000 years ago, and rediscovered by [[archeology|archeologists]] in 1956. The cave was explored by an expedition led by Captain J. M. Thompson in 1935. The team entered the cave by a ladder and found themselves in a chamber some {{convert|800|ft|m|0|order=flip}} in circumference and walked down tunnels over {{convert|1200|ft|m|0|order=flip}} in length.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17221733 |title=Caves and Lakes. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=20 November 1935 |accessdate=6 June 2014 |page=12 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} In the 1960s, the cave was excavated by Alexander Gallus, who found that Aboriginal peoples had mined [[flint]] there.{{cite web|url=http://www.samuseum.sa.gov.au/research/humanities/archaeology/secrets-of-koonalda-caves|title=Secrets of Koonalda Caves|year=2014|accessdate=6 June 2014|publisher=[[South Australian Museum]]}} Koonalda Cave was listed on the [[South Australian Heritage Register]] on 4 March 1993 and inscribed onto the [[Australian National Heritage List]] on 15 October 2014.{{cite web|title=National Heritage Places – Koonalda Cave|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/heritage/places/national/koonalda|publisher=Department of the Environment (Australia)|accessdate=6 May 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://apps.planning.sa.gov.au/HeritageSearch/HeritageItem.aspx?p_heritageno=3 | title=Koonalda Cave, Nullarbor National Park [also on the National Heritage List ID 106022] | publisher=Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources | work=South Australian Heritage Register | accessdate=12 February 2016 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160215213139/http://apps.planning.sa.gov.au/HeritageSearch/HeritageItem.aspx?p_heritageno=3 | archivedate=15 February 2016 | df=dmy-all }} It was also listed on the now-defunct [[Register of the National Estate]].{{cite AHD|106022|Koonalda Cave, Old Eyre Hwy, Cook, SA, Australia }} == See also == * [[List of sinkholes#Sinkholes of Australia|List of sinkholes of Australia]] * [[Warratyi]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Navbox prehistoric caves}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Koonalda Cave}} [[Category:Sinkholes of Australia]] [[Category:Caves of South page.title: List of films featuring miniature people

revision.text:
There is a body of films that feature miniature people. The concept of a human shrinking in size has existed since the beginning of cinema, with early films using camera techniques to change perceptions of human sizes. The earliest film to have a shrunken person was a 1901 short ''[[The Dwarf and the Giant]]'' by [[Georges Méliès]] in which a character was split into two, with one growing in size and the other shrinking. Before digital effects became commonplace, composite screens were used to create the illusion of miniature people. The element appeared in numerous [[B movie]]s.<ref name="zarracina" /> James Luxford, writing for the British Film Institute, said, "Each era has used the scenario for very different purposes, in ways that often reflect the anxieties of the time." He added, "The reason shrinking characters have been so popular in films is that they enable the viewer to see the world in a different way."<ref name="luxford" />
Don Kaye, writing for ''Den of Geek!'', said, "The 'shrinking person' genre got its start in the early ‘30s, with nearly each decade since then offering up its own variation on the theme. Some have been frightening, some humorous and others just plain ludicrous -- but all tap into that deep-seated fear of being diminished in a world that looms too large around us."<ref name="kaye" /> In the 1960s, ''[[Fantastic Voyage]]'' featured miniature people, but no major film revisited the concept until the 1980s. ''[[Grantland]]''{{'}}s Claire L. Evans said during this decade, "The conceit, being inherently silly, was reframed as a vehicle for broad physical comedies and family movies." She said, "These kinds of films reframe domestic life — a bowl of cereal, the family cat — as a cinematic landscape of awe and terror as exotic as anything on an alien world."<ref name="evans" />
==List of films==
<!-- PLEASE ADD A FILM AND ITS CITATION IN ALPHABETICAL ORDER --> {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |- ! scope="col" | Film ! scope="col" | Year(s) ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- | ''{{sortname|The|3 Worlds of Gulliver}}'' || 1960 || The US fantasy film is an adaptation of the 18th-century novel ''[[Gulliver's Travels]]'' and features a voyage during which Dr. Gulliver is perceived as a giant by the small Lilliputian people and is later perceived as small by the giant Brobdingnagian people. The special effects for the different sizes were created by [[Ray Harryhausen]].<ref name="zarracina" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|7th Voyage of Sinbad}}'' || 1957 || The US fantasy film features the hero [[Sinbad the Sailor]] and his ship's crew. In the film, a magician shrinks a princess and provokes her father into declaring war.<ref name="swinney" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Alice in Wonderland (1903 film)|Alice in Wonderland]]'' || 1903 || The British silent film, the first film adaptation of the 19th-century novel ''[[Alice's Adventures in Wonderland]]'', features Alice drinking a liquid to shrink and fit through a door. The shrinking effect is thought to have been accomplished through manipulating lenses.<ref name="luxford" /> |- | ''[[Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)|Alice in Wonderland]]'' || 2010 || The US fantasy film, based on the 19th-century novel ''[[Alice's Adventures in Wonderland]]'', features Alice shrinking and also growing larger in the course of the story.<ref name="kaye" /><ref name="dixon" /><ref name="swinney" /><ref name="zarracina" /> |- | ''[[Amour de poche]]'' (English: ''Girl in his Pocket'') || 1957 || The French comedy fantasy film features a scientist who shrinks his assistant to three inches tall.<ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|Ant Bully|dab=film}}'' || 2006 || The animated family film features a boy who is shrunken down by ants to their size after he kept attacking their colony.<ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Ant-Man (film)|Ant-Man]]'' || 2015 || The US superhero film features [[Ant-Man]], who has the ability to shrink down from his normal human form.<ref name="watercutter" /><ref name="sullivan" /><ref name="evans" /><ref name="kaye" /><ref name="dixon" /><ref name="ulaby" /><ref name="luxford" /><ref name="zarracina" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Ant-Man and the Wasp]]'' || 2018 || The US superhero film features [[Ant-Man]] and the [[Wasp (comics)|Wasp]], who have the ability to shrink down (and grow) from their normal human form.<ref name="hogg" /> |- | ''[[Army of Darkness]]'' || 1992 || The US horror comedy film features a protagonist whose reflection in a mirror is shattered, resulting in multiple tiny figures coming out of each shard.<ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Attack of the Puppet People]]'' || 1958 || The US science fiction horror film features a character who runs a doll factory and is revealed to have been shrinking down humans to the size of dolls.<ref name="schuster" /><ref name="sullivan" /><ref name="kaye" /><ref name="zarracina" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Barbie in the Nutcracker]]'' || 2001 || The computer-animated film features the toy-based character [[Barbie]] who tells the story of "[[The Nutcracker and the Mouse King]]" to her younger sister, in which the Mouse King shrinks down a girl who tries to help the Nutcracker fight against the mouse army.<ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Beetlejuice]]'' || 1988 || The US comedy-fantasy film features a scene in which one of the main characters, Betelgeuse, is shrunken.<ref name="swinney" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|Big Lebowski}}'' || 1998 || In the English-language comedy film, a dream sequence features the protagonist in a shrunken size and running away from a bowling ball.<ref name="swinney" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|Borrowers|dab=1973 film}}'' || 1973 || The US fantasy film, based on a children's novel, features a family of tiny people called Borrowers living in a house who are then discovered by a young boy.<ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|Borrowers|dab=1997 film}}'' || 1997 || The US fantasy film, based on a children's novel, features a family of tiny people called Borrowers living in a house who are then discovered by a young boy.<ref name="swinney" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|Borrowers|dab=2011 film}}'' || 2011 || The British fantasy film, based on a children's novel, features a family of tiny people called Borrowers living in a house who are then discovered by a young boy.<ref name="swinney" /> |- | ''[[Bride of Frankenstein]]'' || 1935 || In the US science fiction horror film, Doctor Septimus Pretorius reveals his collection of [[homunculus|homunculi]] contained in bell jars.<ref name="watercutter" /> |- | ''[[Captain America: Civil War]]'' || 2016 || The superhero film features a variety of superheroes including the shrinking superhero [[Ant-Man]] aiding Captain America and his team.<ref name="williams" /> |- | ''[[Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (film)|Charlie and the Chocolate Factory]]'' || 2005 || In the English-language fantasy film based on the 1964 British novel [[Charlie and the Chocolate Factory|of the same name]], one of the children who won a ticket to tour a chocolate factory accidentally shrinks himself when using a teleporter on himself.<ref name="swinney" /> |- | ''[[Darby O'Gill and the Little People]]'' || 1959 || The US fantasy film features [[leprechaun]]s that are smaller than the humans. Forced perspective was used to depict the difference in size; lights were used abundantly on sets to put everything in focus.<ref name="watercutter" /><ref name="ulaby" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|Devil-Doll}}'' || 1936 || In the US horror film, an escaped convict creates two tiny assassins to kill business associates who had betrayed him.<ref name="edwards" /><ref name="kaye" /><ref name="ulaby" /><ref name="luxford" /><ref name="zarracina" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Dollman (film)|Dollman]]'' || 1991 || The US science fiction film features a space cop who is teleported to Earth and shrunken down to thirteen inches tall.<ref name="sullivan" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Dollman vs. Demonic Toys]]'' || 1993 || The US horror film, a continuation of ''[[Dollman (film)|Dollman]]'' (1991), features a miniature-sized space cop who fights against toys possessed with evil.<ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Downsizing (film)|Downsizing]]'' || 2017 || In the US satire film set in the future, humans are able to be "downsized" (shrunken) to five inches tall as a way to solve overpopulation and global warming.<ref name="watercutter" /><ref name="dixon" /><ref name="ulaby" /><ref name="luxford" /> |- | ''[[Dr. Cyclops]]'' || 1940 || The US science fiction horror film features a biologist who shrinks down visitors that had come to his laboratory in the Amazon jungle, and they escape from him into the jungle.<ref name="watercutter" /><ref name="edwards" /><ref name="kaye" /><ref name="luxford" /><ref name="zarracina" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|Dwarf and the Giant}}'' || 1901 || The silent film is the earliest known to depict a person being shrunken down. Special effects were used to split an actor into two figures, one which shrunk down and one which grew larger.<ref name="ulaby" /><ref name="zarracina" /> |- | ''[[Epic (2013 film)|Epic]]'' || 2013 || In the fantasy adventure film, one of the main protagonists is shrunken down to help a group of little people, known as the Leafmen, prevent their forest home from being destroyed. |- | ''[[Fantastic Voyage]]'' || 1966 || The US science fiction film features a submarine crew that is shrunken down to microscopic size and placed inside a comatose scientist's body to fix the blood clot and revive him.<ref name="schuster" /><ref name="sullivan" /><ref name="evans" /><ref name="edwards" /><ref name="kaye" /><ref name="dixon" /><ref name="ulaby" /><ref name="luxford" /><ref name="swinney" /><ref name="zarracina" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Gulliver's Travels (2010 film)|Gulliver's Travels]]'' || 2010 || The US fantasy film is an adaptation of the 18th-century novel ''[[Gulliver's Travels]]'' and features a voyage during which Gulliver is perceived as a giant by the small Lilliputian people and is later perceived as small by the giant Brobdingnagian people.<ref name="swinney" /> |- | ''[[Honey, I Shrunk the Kids]]'' || 1989 || The US comedy film, set in suburbia, features kids who accidentally shrink themselves with an inventor's experimental shrink ray to be a quarter-inch tall and to survive the indoors and the outdoors on a different scale.<ref name="schuster" /><ref name="sullivan" /><ref name="evans" /><ref name="edwards" /><ref name="kaye" /><ref name="dixon" /><ref name="ulaby" /><ref name="luxford" /><ref name="swinney" /><ref name="zarracina" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Honey, We Shrunk Ourselves]]'' || 1997 || A sequel to ''[[Honey, I Shrunk the Kids]]'' (1989), the US comedy film features the inventor accidentally shrinking himself and three others. They have to get the attention of the kids who think they are home alone.<ref name="kaye" /><ref name="swinney" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Hook (film)|Hook]]'' || 1991 || In the US fantasy film, one of the side characters is the palm-sized fairy [[Tinker Bell]] played by [[Julia Roberts]]. Composites and blue-screen technology were used to depict the fairy as smaller than the others.<ref name="watercutter" /><ref name="swinney" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|Incredible Shrinking Man}}'' || 1957 || The US science fiction horror film features a man who is exposed to a radioactive cloud while on a boating trip. Over time, he begins shrinking and tries to find a cure at the same time he becomes a phenomenon throughout the country.<ref name="watercutter" /><ref name="schuster" /><ref name="sullivan" /><ref name="evans" /><ref name="edwards" /><ref name="kaye" /><ref name="dixon" /><ref name="ulaby" /><ref name="luxford" /><ref name="swinney" /><ref name="zarracina" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|Incredible Shrinking Woman}}'' || 1981 || The US science fiction comedy film features a housewife who accidentally ingests experimental household-product chemicals and begins shrinking. She becomes a media sensation and also the target of a company who wants to use her shrinking nature for evil.<ref name="sullivan" /><ref name="evans" /><ref name="kaye" /><ref name="swinney" /><ref name="zarracina" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|Indian in the Cupboard|dab=film}} || 1995 || The US family film, based on the 1980 children's novel [[The Indian in the Cupboard|of the same name]], features a magical cupboard that brings to life toy figures that the new boy owner puts into it.<ref name="watercutter" /><ref name="swinney" /> |- | ''[[Innerspace]]'' || 1987 || The US science fiction comedy film features a naval aviator who volunteers to be shrunken by miniaturization technology and inserted in a hypochondriac's body. He is pursued by those who also want the technology.<ref name="schuster" /><ref name="sullivan" /><ref name="evans" /><ref name="edwards" /><ref name="kaye" /><ref name="dixon" /><ref name="ulaby" /><ref name="swinney" /><ref name="zarracina" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|Lord of the Rings|dab=film series}}'' film trilogy || 2001–2003 || The fantasy film trilogy features Hobbits, which are two to four feet tall.<ref name="watercutter" /><ref name="ulaby" /> |- | ''[[Mars Attacks!]]'' || 1996 || In the science fiction comedy film, a human general confronting a Martian invader is shrunken down and subsequently crushed by the invader's foot.<ref name="swinney" /> |- | ''[[Mothra (film)|Mothra]]'' || 1961 || In this fantastic Japanese tokusatsu film, two twin women a foot tall, dubbed the Shobijin,are kidnapped from their island and their goddess, Mothra, goes to rescue them. Subsequent films with the character Mothra typically feature the Shobijin, or a variation of them.<ref name="kalat" /> |- | ''[[Mulholland Drive (film)|Mulholland Drive]]'' || 2001 || In the US neo-noir mystery film, one of the main characters meets an elderly couple on a plane who later reappear in her nightmare as tiny figures.<ref name="swinney" /> |- | ''[[Night at the Museum (film series)|Night at the Museum]]'' film trilogy || 2006–2014 || The US fantasy-comedy films feature elements of the [[American Museum of Natural History]] that come to life, including small figurines that become human.<ref name="edwards" /> |- | ''{{sortname|The|Phantom Planet}}'' || 1961 || The US science fiction film features astronauts that are forced to land on an asteroid and discover a humanoid species only six inches tall. The surviving astronaut is subsequently shrunk down to their size and is forced to deal with them.<ref name="schuster" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Tom Thumb (film)|Tom Thumb]]'' || 1958 || The US musical fantasy film is an adaptation of the fairy tale "[[Thumbling]]" and features a tiny boy who is created as a result of a wood-dwelling couple's wishes. The boy eventually gets caught up with human-sized thieves who want to use his size to their advantage.<ref name="swinney" /><ref name="allmovie" /> |- | ''[[Tooth Fairy (2010 film)|Tooth Fairy]]'' || 2010 || The English-language comedy film features a hockey player who is forced to work as a tooth fairy. One of the tools available to the fairy is shrinking paste, which is used in the film.<ref name="swinney" /> |- | ''[[Wild, Wild Planet]]'' || 1966 || The Italian science fiction horror film features a mad scientist who sends bald mutants to kidnap humans and shrink them down to be carried back in suitcases.<ref name="kaye" /> |- | ''[[Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory]]'' || 1971 || In the English-language fantasy film based on the 1964 British novel [[Charlie and the Chocolate Factory|of the same name]], one of the children who won a ticket to tour a chocolate factory accidentally shrinks himself when using a teleporter on himself.<ref name="swinney" /> |}
==See also== TV series featuring miniature people: *''[[Land of the Giants]]'' (1968–1970)<ref name="zarracina" /> *''[[Honey, I Shrunk the Kids: The TV Show]]'' (1997–2000)<ref name="zarracina" /> TV episodes featuring miniature people: *"[[One Little Ship]]", an episode of the TV series ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'' (1993-1999) *"[[Size Matters (Charmed)|Size Matters]]", an episode of the TV series ''[[Charmed]]'' (1998-2006) *"[[I Shrink Therefore I Am]]", an episode of the TV series ''[[Farscape]]'' (1999-2003) *"[[Into the Dalek]]", an episode of the TV series ''[[Doctor Who]]'' *"[[The Flash (season 4)#ep81|Honey, I Shrunk Team Flash]]", an episode of the TV series ''[[The Flash (2014 TV series)|The Flash]]''

{{Multiple issues| {{BLP refimprove|date=June 2018}} {{External links|date=June 2018}} {{Orphan|date=June 2018}}}} {{Infobox philosopher | honorific_prefix = | name = Mahmoud Mehrmohammadi | honorific_suffix = | image = محمود مهر محمدی.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | other_names = | birth_name = <!--only use if different from name--> | birth_date = 1958 | birth_place = Tehran | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = [[Iran]] {{flagicon|IRN}} | religion = Islam | alma_mater = | notable_works = <!-- 'books' parameter deprecated, use 'notable_works' --> | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | era = | region = | school_tradition = | main_interests = [[Teacher Education]], [[human resource development]] | institutions = [[Tarbiat Modares University]] | notable_ideas = | influences = | influenced = [[Elliot Eisner]], [[Joseph Schwab]] | website = {{URL|http://sedayesanad8388.blogfa.com/}} }} '''Mahmoud Mehrmohammadi''' ({{lang-fa|محمود مهرمحمدی}}) is educational scholar, curriculum theorist and faculty member of [[Tarbiat Modares University]]. The domain of his activities and studies is education.<ref name="modares.ac.ir">{{cite web|url=http://www.modares.ac.ir/en/Schools/hum/Academic_Staff/~mehrm_ma/7|title=خطا|website=Modares.ac.ir|accessdate=5 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.injoeas.com/member/dr%20mahmoud%20mehrmohamadi.pdf# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2014-06-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714143202/http://www.injoeas.com/member/dr%20mahmoud%20mehrmohamadi.pdf# |archive-date=2014-07-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Biography== Mahmoud Mehrmohammadi was born in 1958 in [[Tehran]]. Graduated from high school in 1975 and went to the US to continue his studies. Obtained a BS in Industrial Technology, Building construction in 1979 from California State University- Fresno. He then went to San Jose- California to study for his Masters. Majoring this time in the field of education he opted to study educational technology and obtained his degree 1n 1981. For PhD he chose [[University of Southern California]] (USC) and studied in the department of Curriculum and Instruction from 1985 to 1987.
Upon returning home he assumed the position of the director for the Center for Educational Planning in the ministry of higher education and taught simultaneously in many universities. He is former chancellor of a national teacher education university named [[Farhangian University]]. He has published about 10 books and around 100 papers in the field. Most of his works aim at offering a new perspective about commonplaces of the education system.<ref>[http://icqhec.khuisf.ac.ir/page.php?slct_pg_id=88&sid=1&slc_lang=fa Prof. Dr. Mahmud Mehrmohamadi, Tarbiat Modares University, Iran] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017075251/http://icqhec.khuisf.ac.ir/page.php?slct_pg_id=88&sid=1&slc_lang=fa |date=2014-10-17 }}</ref>
== Scientific works (in English) == *International Journals: 1- 'Needs Based Curriculum Development Process', International Research Journal of Arts and Humanities, Vol. 36, No. 36, pp. 59–51 *Refereed International Conference Proceedings: 1-'Internet and the Muslim Youth: Challenges, paradigms and strategies', Regional Seminar to Consider Ways to Immunize Children against Harmful Internet Content, Malaysia. 2-'Imaginative Perception: The Hallmark of Reflective Action ', IAACS Triennial Conference, 00/00/2009, South Africa. *Papers: The Place of Neuroscience in Curriculum Thought and Practice, Recognition of "technology education" as a null aspect of school, A Conceptual Framework for Popularizing Science in Muslim societies, Teaching and Learning Road Map for Schools: Global and yet Local!, Upside down Curriculum Design (UDCD): A Novel Strategy in Making Curricular Decisions in Professional Fields of Study, A Comparative Analysis of Ghazali and Egan's Views on Imagination and Education: the Mythic Understanding and Children Learning, Needs-Based Curriculum Development Process: A Multilevel Conception, Toward a New Conception of Educated Person...<ref>{{cite web|url=https://modares.academia.edu/mahmoudmehrmohammadi|title=mahmoud mehrmohammadi - Tarbiat Modares University |website=Modares.academia.edu|accessdate=5 June 2018}}</ref>
==Awards== * Outstanding Professor at Tarbiat Modares University, 2004, Tarbiat Modares University * Outstanding researcher award, 2012, International Farabi Festival on the Humanities and Islamic Studies * Outstanding professor award at the national level, Humanitis, 2008, Ministry of Science, Research and technology * Outstanding Doctoral Dissertation Supervisor Award, 2009, Vice president's office for Science and Technology<ref name="modares.ac.ir"/>
==Research interests== * Approaches to Curriculum Development / Design * Curriculum Research Methodology * Art and The Curriculum * Hidden Curriculum * Curriculum Integration * Comparative Studies in Curriculum * Teaching - Learning Strategies * Higher Education Curriculum<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.modares.ac.ir/uploads/EnResume.mehrm_ma.pdf|title=Curriculum Vitae of Mahmoud Mehrmohammadi at Tarbiat Modares University|website=Modares.ac.ir|accessdate=5 June 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Commons category|Mahmoud Mehrmohammadi}} {{Reflist}}

'''Makonde art''' is the [[art]] of the [[Makonde people]].
Makonde art can be subdivided into different areas. The Makonde traditionally carve household objects, figures and masks. After the 1930s, the Portuguese colonizers and other missionaries arrived at the [[Makonde plateau]]. They immediately showed great interest and fascination for the Makonde wood carvings and began to order different pieces, from religious to political “eminences.” The Makonde sculptors, after noticing such interest, decided to carve the new pieces using pau-preto (ebony wood, Diospyros ebenum) and pau-rosa (Swartzia spp.) instead of the soft and non long-lasting wood they had used before. This first contact with the Western culture can be considered to be the first introduction of the classical European style into the traditional Makonde style.Since the 1950s years the socalled Modern Makonde Art has been developed. An essential step was the turning to abstract figures, mostly spirits, [[Shetani]], that play a special role. This shetani style originated in the early 1950s by master carver [[Samaki Likankoa]], whose patron [[Mohamed Peera]], an art curator in Tanzania played an instrumental and decisive role in influencing the modern makonde art movement. Some Makonde sculptors, the best known of whom is [[George Lugwani]], have embraced fully abstract style of carving without discernible figures. Makonde are also part of the important contemporary artists of Africa today. The most internationally acknowledged such artist was [[George Lilanga]].
The ex libris of ritual Makonde art are the unique Mapiko masks (singular: Lipiko), which have been used in coming-of-age rituals since before contact was made with missionaries, in the 19th century. These masks are painstakingly carved from a single block of light wood (usually 'sumaumeira brava') and may represent spirits ('shetani'), ancestors, or living characters (real or idealized). The dancer wears them so that he sees through the mask's mouth and the mask faces straight when he bends forward. Examples of such masks are provided in the second row of pictures below.
<gallery> Image:Makonde carving_1.jpg Image:Makonde carving_1_detail_1.jpg Image:Makonde carving_2.jpg Image:Makonde elephant.jpg Image:Lugwani.jpg|An abstract carving by George Lugwani in [[African Blackwood|mpingo]]. </gallery>
==See also== *[[Shetani]] *[[Makonde chess set]]

{{Infobox civilian attack |title=Manila Hostage Crisis |image=2010 Manila hostage crisis bus.JPG |image_size=226px |caption=The bus where the hostages were held captive. |location=[[Quirino Grandstand]], [[Rizal Park]], [[Manila]], Philippines |coordinates={{Coord|14.58104|120.974922|display=inline,title}} |target= Hong Kong tourists on board a bus |date=Monday, August 23, 2010 |time=10:00–21:00 |timezone=[[UTC+08:00]] |type=[[Hostage crisis]], [[siege]], [[mass murder]] |fatalities= 9 (including the perpetrator)<ref name="hkgovt-victimlist">{{Cite news|title=Manila hostage incident victim name list|url=http://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201008/24/P201008240172.htm|accessdate=August 24, 2010|newspaper=Hong Kong's Information Services Department Press Release|date=August 24, 2010}}</ref><ref name="rolando">{{Cite news|last=Conde|first=Carlos|title=Gunman and 8 Hostages Dead in the Philippines|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/24/world/asia/24phils.html?partner=rss&emc=rss|accessdate=August 24, 2010|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 23, 2010}}</ref> |injuries= 9 (7 hostages and 2 bystanders) |perp =Rolando Mendoza<ref name="rolando"/> |weapons = * [[M16 rifle#XM16E1 and M16A1 (Colt Model 603)|XM16E1 rifle]] * [[Handgun]] * [[Knife]] }}
The '''Manila hostage crisis''', officially known as the '''Rizal Park hostage-taking incident''',<ref name="IIRC" /> took place when a disgruntled former [[Philippine National Police]] officer named Rolando Mendoza hijacked a tourist bus in [[Rizal Park]], [[Manila]], [[Philippines]] on August 23, 2010. The bus carried 25 people: 20 tourists, a tour guide from [[Hong Kong]], and four local Filipinos. Mendoza claimed that he had been unfairly dismissed from his job, and demanded a fair hearing to defend himself.<ref name=robles/><ref name=BWTimeline>Gregorio, Ann Rozainne R. (August 24, 2010).[http://www.bworldonline.com/main/content.php?id=16456 Timeline: Manila hostage crisis] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923221512/http://www.bworldonline.com/main/content.php?id=16456 |date=September 23, 2015 }}. ''[[BusinessWorld]]''.</ref>
Negotiations (which were broadcast live on television and the internet) broke down dramatically about ten hours into the stand-off, when the police arrested Mendoza's brother and thus incited Mendoza to open fire.<ref name="driver" /> The bus driver managed to escape, and declared "Everyone is dead" before he was whisked away by policemen.<ref name="DriverEscapes">{{cite news|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/video/nation/metro-manila/08/23/10/driver-escapes-says-no-one-alive-bus|title=Driver escapes, says 'hostages all dead'|date=August 23, 2010|publisher=ABS-CBN News|language=tl}}</ref> Following a 90-minute gun battle, Mendoza and eight of the hostages were killed and several others injured.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle09.asp?xfile=data/international/2010/August/international_August1258.xml&section=international|title=9 killed in Manila hostage drama|first=Gina|last=Abuyuan|publisher=Khaleej Times|date=August 23, 2010|accessdate=April 23, 2011}}</ref>
The Philippine and Hong Kong governments conducted separate investigations into the incident. Both inquiries concluded that the Philippine officials' poor handling of the situation caused the eight hostages' deaths.<ref name="ReportDelivery" /><ref name="bbc20110323">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12827835|publisher=BBC|title=Hong Kong inquest criticises Philippines on bus hijack|date=March 23, 2011|accessdate=April 19, 2011}}</ref> The assault mounted by the [[Manila Police District]] (MPD), and the resulting shoot-out, have been widely criticized by [[pundit (expert)|pundits]] as "bungled" and "incompetent",<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/philippines/7961669/Hostage-rescue-team-bungled-Philippines-coach-rescue.html|title=Hostage rescue team 'bungled Philippines coach rescue'|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|date=August 24, 2010|accessdate=April 23, 2011}}</ref> and the [[Government of Hong Kong|Hong Kong Government]] has issued a "black" [[travel alert]] for the Philippines as a result of the affair.<ref name="bbc310" />
On April 12, 2018, Philippine president [[Rodrigo Duterte]] publicly apologized for the incident on behalf of his country.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://politics.com.ph/after-8-years-of-silence-duterte-says-sorry-to-china-hk-over-2010-luneta-hostage-crisis/|title=After 8 years of silence: Duterte says sorry to China, HK over 2010 Luneta hostage crisis|last=|first=|date=Apr 12, 2018|work=Politiko|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
==Perpetrator== Rolando Mendoza graduated from the [[Philippine College of Criminology]] with a degree in criminology, joined the Philippine National Police force as a patrolman, and rose to become senior inspector.<ref name="who_is_this">{{Cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20100823-288385/Who-is-this-hostage-taking-cop |title=Who is this hostage-taking cop? |first=Alcuin |last=Papa |work=Philippine Daily Inquirer |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 23, 2010}}</ref> He was decorated 17 times for bravery and honor, and was described by colleagues as hard-working and kind.<ref name=robles>Robles, Alan (August 24, 2010). "Disgrace of a model policeman thrown out of force for corruption", ''South China Morning Post''</ref> In February 1986, Mendoza led a group of policemen that accosted a van carrying 13 crates full of money, which former Philippine president and dictator [[Ferdinand Marcos]] was apparently trying to smuggle out of the country. Mendoza and his team turned the shipment over to authorities,<ref name=robles/> for which he was declared one of the Ten Outstanding Policemen of the Philippines by the [[Junior Chamber International|Jaycees International]] that year.<ref name="who_is_this" />
On April 9, 2008, hotel chef Christian Kalaw alleged that he was accosted by Mendoza and several other officers over a parking violation. Kalaw alleged that the police planted sachets of [[methamphetamine]] in his car, forced him to take the drug, and accused him of being a drug addict. The officers also allegedly demanded Kalaw access his bank ATM and hand over money. Kalaw said the policemen released him after a friend raised 20,000 pesos on his behalf. The [[Philippine Ombudsman|Office of the Ombudsman]] found Mendoza and four others guilty of misconduct, and ordered Mendoza's dismissal from the service and the voiding of all his benefits.<ref name=robles/> In late April 2008, he was relieved as Chief of the Mobile Patrol Unit. In August 2008, the Eighth Division of the Manila Prosecutors' Office vacated the case after Kalaw failed to attend the dismissal proceedings, and in October the PNP Internal Affairs Service recommended the case be dropped. Mendoza's brother, Gregorio, later stated that all his brother wanted was a fair hearing by the Ombudsman, who "never even gave him a chance to defend himself; they [just] immediately dismissed him."<ref name=robles/>
There were later reports that Mendoza was also charged with gang rape in a 1996 incident, but the case was dismissed when the complainants did not show up at court.<ref name=rape>[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/08/30/10/hostage-taker-also-faced-gang-rape-charges Hostage-taker also faced gang rape charges]. (August 30, 2010). ABS-CBN News.</ref>
==Hijacking==
===Boarding=== {{location map+ |Metro Manila |float=right |height=400 |width=220 |caption=Locations of key places during the hostage crisis. Rizal Park is about 10 km away from the Office of the Ombudsman. |places= {{location map~ |Metro Manila |marksize=8|lat=14.582 |long=120.9743 |label=Bus |position=left}} {{location map~ |Metro Manila |marksize=8|lat=14.5835 |long=120.9864 |label=Manila Police HQ|position=top}} {{location map~ |Metro Manila |marksize=8|lat=14.6492 |long=121.0408 |label=Ombudsman|position=right}} {{location map~ |Metro Manila |marksize=8|lat=14.5640 |long=120.9863 |label=Ospital ng Maynila|position=right}} {{location map~ |Metro Manila |marksize=8|lat=14.5788 |long=120.9867 |label=PGH |position=right}} }}
On the morning of August 23, 2010, Mendoza attempted to board a [[Hong Thai Travel Services]] tour bus as it was taking on riders. Mendoza requested a free ride, and when he was declined by the driver, Mendoza brandished a weapon, handcuffed the driver to the steering wheel and hijacked the bus.<ref name="nataliewong">{{cite web|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=11&art_id=102088&sid=29349481&con_type=1&d_str=20100824&fc=1|author=Natalie Wong|work=The Standard|location=Hong Kong|title=Tour leader calmly sent SOS to office|date=August 24, 2010|accessdate=August 24, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XEw2Uty?url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=11&art_id=102088&sid=29349481&con_type=1&d_str=20100824&fc=1|archivedate=June 19, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> There are conflicting reports as to whether Mendoza boarded in front of [[Quirino Grandstand]] at [[Rizal Park]], or at [[Fort Santiago]]; a number of witnesses saw a man answering Mendoza's description boarding the bus at the latter location.<ref name=driver/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Ramos|first1=Marlon|date=August 27, 2010|title=NBI probing who brought hostage-taker to Fort Santiago|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer}}</ref>
In any event, Mendoza, armed with a handgun and an [[M16 rifle]],<ref name=alone>Chong, Dennis (August 26, 2010). [http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=102194&sid=29375134&con_type=3&d_str=20100826&sear_year=2010 "Police may go it alone in deaths probe"] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/68XEzVErz?url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=102194&sid=29375134&con_type=3&d_str=20100826&sear_year=2010 |date=June 19, 2012 }}, ''The Standard'' (Hong Kong)</ref> commandeered the tour bus, demanded reinstatement to his previous post with benefits,<ref name="DriverEscapes"/> and claimed he was framed. [[Mayor of Manila|Manila mayor]] [[Alfredo Lim]] said he would grant Mendoza's wish to be reinstated if he could prove his case.<ref name="HostageRef3">{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=605434&publicationSubCategoryId=200 |title=Lim calls for review of Manila hostage-taker's case |first=Dennis |last=Carcamo |date=August 23, 2010 |work=The Philippine Star |location=Manila, Philippines |accessdate=August 23, 2010}}</ref>
Masa Tse Ting-chunn, the bus' tour guide, immediately called his agency in Hong Kong shortly after 10:30 am. During the two-minute conversation, Tse calmly informed the customer services manager that his group was being held hostage.<ref name="nataliewong"/> Initial media reports were confusing and contradictory; the suspect was alternatively identified as "Ronaldo," "Rolando" and "Reynaldo"; and the hostages aboard were initially reported to be South Koreans<ref name=media>Jemandre, Tessa. (August 27, 2010). [http://www.gmanews.tv/story/199551/how-the-media-covered-the-grandstand-carnage How the media covered the Grandstand carnage]. GMA News.</ref> before they were confirmed to be mostly from Hong Kong.
===Negotiations=== Almost an hour later, six Hong Kong tourists were freed<ref name="HostageRef4">{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=605437&publicationSubCategoryId=200 |title=6 freed in Manila hostage drama |first=Dennis |last=Carcamo |date=August 23, 2010 |work=The Philippine Star |location=Manila, Philippines |accessdate=August 23, 2010 |quote= Six hostages, including three children have been released to police by a dismissed police officer who took hijacked a bus carrying 25 tourists in Manila, a radio report said.}}</ref>— an elderly couple, a woman with two young children, and a 12-year-old boy. Two Filipino photographers boarded the bus as volunteer hostages in exchange for the releases.<ref name="IIRC">{{citation|url=http://www.gov.ph/2010/09/17/first-report-of-the-iirc-on-the-rizal-park-hostage-taking-incident/|title=First Report of the INCIDENT INVESTIGATION and REVIEW COMMITTEE on the August 23, 2010 Rizal Park Hostage-taking Incident: SEQUENCE OF EVENTS, EVALUATION and RECOMMENDATIONS|date=September 16, 2010|publisher=Incident Investigation and Review Committee|pages=9–10, 16, 22, 24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/199183/ex-cop-holds-tourist-bus-passengers-hostage-in-manila |title=Ex-cop holds tourist bus passengers hostage in Manila |work=GMANews.tv |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 23, 2010}}</ref>
By noon, three additional hostages, including the Filipino tour guide and the two photographers who volunteered to be taken hostage, had also been released.<ref name="IIRC" /> [[TV5 (Philippines)|TV5]] news anchor [[Erwin Tulfo]] remained in contact with Mendoza, while superintendent Orlando Yebra and chief inspector Romeo Salvador led negotiations. Seventeen people remained on the bus.<ref name="9th_hostage">{{Cite news |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20100823-288388/9th-hostage-freed-17-others-left-onboard-bus |title=9th hostage freed, 17 others left onboard [sic] bus |author=Jeannette Andrade, Cathy Miranda |work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]], INQUIRER.net |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 23, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XF4ahU5?url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20100823-288388/9th-hostage-freed-17-others-left-onboard-bus |archivedate=June 19, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> By this time, television channels all over the world were preempting their programs with non-stop live coverage of the hostage situation. Philippine television stations [[ABS-CBN]], [[GMA Network|GMA]], [[TV5 (Philippines)|TV5]] and government-run [[People's Television Network|NBN (now PTV)]], as well as Hong Kong television station [[Television Broadcasts Limited|TVB]] and [[CNN]], all provided live coverage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.rti.org.tw/index_newsContent.aspx?id=8&id2=2&nid=255404|title=菲人質事件陷僵局 槍手貼出字條「3p.m. dead lock」 (Chinese)|publisher=Radio Taiwan International|date=2010-08-23|accessdate=2010-08-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XF5GVpB?url=http://news.rti.org.tw/index_newsContent.aspx?id=8&id2=2&nid=255404|archivedate=June 19, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> However, because the news networks were filming police activity, and the bus was equipped with a television, the gunman was able to watch the police action and determine the locations of snipers.<ref name="9th_hostage" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Hong Kong criticizes handling of Manila hostage crisis|publisher=Reuters|date=August 23, 2010|accessdate=July 14, 2011|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/08/23/us-philippines-hostage-hongkong-idUSTRE67M35B20100823}}</ref> At around 2 pm, Mendoza posted several notes on the windows, which read "A big mistake to correct. A big wrong decision", "Big deal will start after 3 pm today" and "3 pm deadlock".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=12&art_id=102199&sid=29385359&con_type=3&d_str=20100827&fc=2|title=Itinerary of death|first1=Dennis|last1=Chong|first2=Serinah|last2=Ho|publisher=The Standard|location=Hong Kong|date=August 27, 2010|accessdate=July 14, 2011}}</ref>
Shortly after sundown, the [[Philippine Ombudsman|Office of the Ombudsman]] denied Mendoza's request to be reinstated to the police force, but assured him that his case would be reopened. Manila Vice-Mayor [[Isko Moreno]] delivered the Ombudsman's letter to the hostage scene.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://business.inquirer.net/money/breakingnews/view/20100823-288413/Negotiators-deliver-letter-from-Ombudsman |title=Policeman’s demand for reinstatement nixed |author=Cathy C. Yamsuan, Tetch Torres |work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |publisher=INQUIRER.net |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 23, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XFEwBMe?url=http://business.inquirer.net/money/breakingnews/view/20100823-288413/Negotiators-deliver-letter-from-Ombudsman |archivedate=June 19, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Mendoza called the Ombudsman's decision "garbage", claiming that it did not answer his demands.<ref name=driver/> Mayor Lim later claimed on local radio that authorities{{who|date=March 2014}} had agreed to reinstate Mendoza to bring an end to the crisis, but had not been able to deliver the message due to bad traffic.<ref name=alfredo>Chong, Dennis &agencies (August 25, 2010). "Letter reinstating Mendoza stuck in traffic", ''The Standard''</ref><ref>[http://www.manilastandardtoday.com/insideNews.htm?f=2010/august/25/news2.isx&d=2010/august/25 "Police were ready to reinstate hostage-taker at the last minute"], ''Manila Standard Today''</ref>
When the Manila Police District (MPD) SWAT team arrived, Mendoza declared in a radio interview with [[DZXL]] that he would kill the passengers if the SWAT team did not leave.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20100823-288419/Police-hostage-taker-threatens-to-kill-hostages |title=Police hostage-taker threatens to kill hostages |work=[[Agence France-Presse]] (AFP) |publisher=INQUIRER.net |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 23, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XFKrvFD?url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20100823-288419/Police-hostage-taker-threatens-to-kill-hostages |archivedate=June 19, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> His brother, [[Philippine National Police#Non-commissioned officers|SPO2]] Gregorio Mendoza, walked out after trying to negotiate with him. He urged Mendoza to surrender peacefully, saying, "Nothing [bad] will happen here."<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20100823-288420/Hostage-taking-cops-brother-walks-out-of-negotiations |title=Hostage-taking cop’s brother walks out of negotiations |first=Jeannette |last=Andrade |work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 23, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XFLXcIk?url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20100823-288420/Hostage-taking-cops-brother-walks-out-of-negotiations |archivedate=June 19, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Gregorio Mendoza was then arrested for breaching the exclusion zone while carrying a gun, as he did not have the MPD's approval to assist in the negotiations.<ref name="Shots fired">{{Cite news|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/199224/shots-fired-in-manila-hostage-crisis-report |title=Shots fired in Manila hostage crisis — report |work=GMANews.tv |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 23, 2010}}</ref><ref name="President Aquino: SPO2 Gregorio Mendoza in custody">{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/ANCALERTS |title=President Aquino: SPO2 Gregorio Mendoza in custody |work=ANC News |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 23, 2010}}</ref> President Aquino later said that the gunman's brother had contributed to the deterioration of the situation, by fanning Mendoza's hatred of the negotiators.<ref name=alfredo/>
===Assault=== Mendoza became agitated when he witnessed live coverage of his brother's arrest from the bus television. Reports indicated that Mendoza fired warning shots as he saw his brother being carried away.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20100823-288425/Dismissed-cop-kills-most-of-Chinese-hostagestourist-bus-driver|author1=Jeannette Andrade|author2=Marlon Ramos|author3=DJ Yap|title=Dismissed cop kills most of Chinese hostages—tourist bus driver |publisher=INQUIRER.net |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 28, 2010}}</ref> Mendoza demanded that the police release his brother, or else he would start executing hostages, and a few minutes later claimed on live radio that he had, indeed, already shot two hostages.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20100823-288422/Gunman-tells-live-radio-he-shot-two-Hong-Kong-hostages |title=Gunman tells live radio he shot two Hong Kong hostages |work=Agence France-Presse (AFP) |publisher=INQUIRER.net |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 23, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XFNfy2A?url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20100823-288422/Gunman-tells-live-radio-he-shot-two-Hong-Kong-hostages |archivedate=June 19, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/08/30/10/transcript-hostage-takers-last-radio-interview |title=Transcript of hostage-taker's last radio interview|publisher=abs-cbnNEWS.com|date=August 30, 2010|accessdate=July 13, 2011}}</ref>
The first shots fired from within the bus were heard at about 7:21 pm. At around the same time, it was reported that snipers had shot the tires immobilizing the bus after it had attempted to move.<ref name="Shots fired"/><ref name=GMAtimeline>Abella, Jerrie, Pia Faustino, et al. (August 24, 2010). [http://www.gmanews.tv/story/199258/massacre-in-nations-heart-timeline-of-manila-bus-siege Massacre in nation's heart: Timeline of Manila bus siege]. GMA News. Retrieved August 26, 2010.</ref> Mendoza first killed Masa Tse, the tour leader whom he had handcuffed to the door handrail earlier.<ref name=malaya>Africa, Raymond & Bengo, Regina (August 25, 2010), [http://www.malaya.com.ph/08252010/news1.html "The morning after"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100829140648/http://www.malaya.com.ph/08252010/news1.html |date=August 29, 2010 }}, ''The Malaya'' (Manila)</ref> According to survivor Joe Chan Kwok-chu, several hostages tried to rush Mendoza as he was preparing to shoot the other hostages, but he shot them down before they could reach him.<ref name="joechan-account">{{zh-hk icon}}{{Cite news|url=http://news.hkheadline.com/dailynews/content_hk/2010/08/26/120666.asp |title= 倖存團友︰槍手逐個屠殺 |publisher=Headline Daily |date=August 26, 2010 |accessdate=August 30, 2010}}</ref>
At around 7:30pm, bus driver Alberto Lubang escaped the bus. Thinking that all remaining hostages had died, Lubang cried ''"Patay na lahat...!"'' ("Everyone is dead...!") to the policemen and media.<ref name="driver" /><ref name="DriverEscapes" /> He later admitted that his assumption was based on witnessing Mendoza shoot three hostages and firing additional shots at others.<ref name=driver>{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/-depth/08/24/10/bus-driver-hostage-taker-got-mad-after-brods-arrest|title=Bus driver: Hostage-taker got mad after brod's arrest|work=[[ABS-CBN News]]|date=August 24, 2010 |accessdate=August 24, 2010}}</ref>
Mendoza then began shooting the rest of the hostages one by one, aiming at each of their heads.<ref name="joechan-account" /> Amy Leung Ng Yau-woon told of how her husband Ken Leung Kam-wing shielded her with his body and saved her from harm while sacrificing his own life.<ref name="my-husband-thestandard">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=13&art_id=102084&sid=29349232&con_type=3|title='My husband died shielding me with his body'|publisher=The Standard, Hong Kong|date=August 24, 2010|accessdate=August 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XFl7HH9?url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=13&art_id=102084&sid=29349232&con_type=3|archivedate=June 19, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Similarly, their daughter Jessie Leung Song-yi took two bullets while protecting her older brother, and died as a result.<ref name="jessieleung-sacrifice">{{zh-hk icon}}{{Cite news|url=http://news.hkheadline.com/dailynews/content_hk/2010/08/26/120667.asp |title= 梁家幼女為兄擋兩槍犧牲 |publisher=Headline Daily |date=August 26, 2010 |accessdate=August 30, 2010}}</ref> Passenger Joe Chan shielded himself from Mendoza's gunfire with his backpack and survived, but both of his wrists were shattered.<ref name="joechan-account" /> Chan's traveling companion was seriously injured by a gunshot to her chin.<ref name="hkgovt-victimlist" />
The SWAT team started to surround the bus at 7:37 pm.<ref name=GMAtimeline/> The policemen attempted for nearly an hour to enter the bus, first by breaking its Plexi glass windows with sledgehammers, pulling the door with a rope attached to a police vehicle but it snapped. After running out of choices, they threw two canisters of tear gas inside and Mendoza stepped out of the bus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/6580162-excop-holds-tourist-bus-passengers-hostage-in-manila |title=Manila Hostage Drama: During and After Story and Pictures |work=ALLVOICES.com |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 23, 2010}}</ref> Snipers, who had taken positions earlier in the day, ultimately shot Mendoza in the head after he exited the bus, killing him instantly. By that time, however, four more hostages were confirmed dead, while only six hostages were confirmed alive and not seriously injured.<ref name="conclusion">{{Cite news|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/199231/hostage-crisis-ends-in-bloody-carnage-4-hostages-dead |title=Hostage crisis ends in bloody carnage; 4 hostages dead |first=Jerrie |last=Abella |work=GMANews.tv |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 23, 2010}}</ref> Two other people outside the bus — 47-year-old [[TVB]] news crew engineer Wen Ming, and child bystander Mike Ladrillo y Campanero — were wounded by stray bullets.<ref name="nataliewong"/><ref name="ladrillo">{{cite web|url=http://martinoei.wordpress.com/2010/08/25/%E6%88%91%E6%83%B3%E5%BA%B7%E6%B3%B0%E8%A7%A3%E9%87%8B%E4%B8%80%E4%B8%8B%E4%BB%A5%E4%B8%8B%E8%8F%B2%E5%BE%8B%E8%B3%93%E5%B7%AE%E9%A4%A8%E5%98%85%E6%96%87%E4%BB%B6/|title=Spot Report re: Hostage Taking Incident|publisher=Manila Police District via [[Next Magazine (Chinese magazine)|Next Magazine]] and [[:zh:黃世澤|Martin Oei]]|date=August 23, 2010|accessdate=August 28, 2010}}</ref><ref name="WenMing">{{zh-hk icon}}{{Cite news|title= 記者中流彈擦傷 裝器材鐵箱當護盾 | work=Ming Pao |location=Hong Kong |date=August 24, 2010 }}</ref>
==Aftermath== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:ManilaHostageAftermath.jpg|thumb|Members of the Manila Police District (MPD) stand guard meters away from the tourist bus the day after{{ifdc|File_name.ext|log=2011 June 14}}]] -->
===Hostages=== Six of the surviving hostages were taken to [[Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center]], where two later died;<ref name="conclusion"/> two were taken to the [[Philippine General Hospital]];<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9HP7UF00.htm |title=Hospitals: 6 out of 15 bus hostages dead |first=Jim |last=Gomez |agency=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 24, 2010}}</ref> the remaining seven hostages were taken to Manila Doctors Hospital.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-08/24/c_13460152.htm |title=3 injured Hong Kong hostages in stable condition: doctors |publisher=Xinhua News Agency |date=August 24, 2010 |accessdate=August 25, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XFrx4g9?url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-08/24/c_13460152.htm |archivedate=June 19, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> There were eight total fatalities. The 13 survivors had injuries which ranged from minor to substantial.<ref name="Police admit blunders">{{Cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20100824-288510/Police-admit-blunders-in-hostage-crisis |title=Police admit blunders in hostage crisis |work=Agence France-Presse |publisher=INQUIRER.net |date=August 24, 2010 |accessdate=August 24, 2010}}</ref>
Because the bus driver Alberto Lubang had escaped the bus minutes before the situation deteriorated, despite his claim that he had been handcuffed to the steering wheel, suspicions arose that he was in fact the gunman's accomplice,<ref>Staff reporter (August 25, 2010). [http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=102139&sid=29358487&con_type=1&d_str=20100825&sear_year=2010 "Bus driver feels heat"] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/68XFtOoPr?url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=102139&sid=29358487&con_type=1&d_str=20100825&sear_year=2010 |date=June 19, 2012 }}, ''The Standard'' (Hong Kong)</ref> which Lubang denied.<ref name=driver/> However, on August 27, 2010, Lubang and his family were reported missing and had fled their home, possibly going into hiding.<ref>[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/metro-manila/08/26/10/tourist-bus-driver-missing "Tourist bus driver missing?"], abs-cbnNEWS.com. August 27, 2010</ref>
The list of the eight identified victims<ref name="hkgovt-victimlist"/><ref>{{zh-hk icon}}{{Cite news|title= 機警媽媽撒謊救小團友 11歲童幸逃離 父母中槍雙亡 |work=[[Ming Pao]] |location=Hong Kong |date=August 24, 2010 }}</ref> included Ken Leung (梁錦榮), his two daughters Doris Leung Chung-see (梁頌詩), 21, and Jessie Leung Song-yi (梁頌儀), 14 (his son Jason Leung (梁頌學) was seriously injured)<ref name=teen>Lee, Ella; Wong, Martin & Lam, Anita (August 26, 2010). "Teen fights for life in hospital, but cause of head injury unclear", ''[[South China Morning Post]]''</ref> Wong Tze-lam (汪子林) and his wife Yeung Yee-wa (楊綺華) and her sister Yeung Yee-kam (楊綺琴); and Fu Cheuk-yan (傅卓仁).<ref name=fortunatefew>Lam, Anita; Wong, Martin; Eng, Dennis & Lo, Clifford (Aug 25, 2010). "The casualties and the fortunate few", ''South China Morning Post'' ('''note''': The journal erroneously wrote: "''Wong Tze-lam, 51, his wife, Yeung Yee-kam, 46, and sister-in-law, Yeung Yee-wa, 44 (all dead), the couple's son, Jason Wong Ching-yat, 12 (set free), and daughter Tracey Wong Cheuk-yiu, 15 (injured)''")</ref>
[[Donald Tsang]], [[Chief Executive of Hong Kong]], offered for the eight victims to be buried in the {{ill|Tribute Garden|zh|景仰園}} (景仰園), a part of [[Wo Hop Shek Public Cemetery]] designated for Hongkongers who showed extraordinary acts of bravery to save others.<ref>Special burial offered for hostage victims, ''South China Morning Post'' (August 28, 2010)</ref> Fu and the three members of the Wong family accepted the offer and were buried at Tribute Garden.<ref>{{zh-hk icon}} {{cite news|title=四名遇難者 安葬景仰園|publisher=[[Apple Daily]]|date=September 2, 2010}}</ref> On 1 July 2011, {{ill|Masa Tse|zh|謝廷駿}} (謝廷駿, [[:zh-yue:謝廷駿|ZH-YUE]]), Fu Cheuk-yan and Ken Leung Kam-wing were all posthumously awarded the Gold Medal for Bravery by the Hong Kong government.<ref>{{zh-hk icon}}{{cite news|title=家人祭告謝廷駿獲授勳|publisher=[[Sing Tao Daily]]|date=July 2, 2011|url=http://news.sina.com.hk/news/5/1/1/2371112/1.html}}</ref> Mendoza's parents apologized and begged forgiveness from the Hong Kong government for their son's actions.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}
===Investigations by the Philippine government=== President Aquino ordered a thorough investigation, and for a report to be issued within three weeks. The investigation was held by the Post Critical Incident Management Committee (PCIMC), under the auspices of the Joint Incident Investigation and Review Committee (JIIRC), headed by former Secretary of Justice [[Leila de Lima]].<ref name=doj>{{cite news|last1=Avendaño|first1=Christine O.|last2=Papa|first2=Alcuin|last3=Kwok|first3=Abigail|date=August 30, 2010|title=DOJ chief the only spokesperson on hostage crisis probe—Palace|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer}}</ref> As a gesture of transparency towards the Hong Kong government, the Aquino government invited the [[Hong Kong Police Force]] to send a team to observe the investigation.<ref>Gil C. Cabacungan Jr. (August 31, 2010). [http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20100831-289628/Honasan-Allowing-HK-cops-in-hostage-taking-probe-a-gesture-of-transparency "Honasan: Allowing HK cops in hostage-taking probe a gesture of transparency"] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/68XG5I2rr?url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20100831-289628/Honasan-Allowing-HK-cops-in-hostage-taking-probe-a-gesture-of-transparency |date=June 19, 2012 }}, ''Philippine Daily Inquirer''</ref><ref>{{zh-hk icon}}{{Cite news|url=http://news.hkheadline.com.hk/dailynews/content_hk/2010/08/30/121038.asp|newspaper=Headline News |date=August 30, 2010 |accessdate=August 31, 2010 |title= 菲律賓發聲明 港警不能插手}}</ref> De Lima declared a gag order to cover all parties and departments, including the Hong Kong team examining evidence on the ground.<ref name=doj/>
Preliminary results of the official investigation were released on August 31, 2010. Ballistic tests showed that the deceased hostages' wounds were caused by a high-calibre weapon fired from within the coach. Of the 65 recovered M16 rifle cartridges from the coach, 58 came from Mendoza's gun, making it nearly certain that the eight deceased hostage were killed by Mendoza.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://paper.thestandard.com.hk/Default.htm?href=TheStandard%2F2010%2F08%2F31&pageno=3&view=document |title=Forensic team examines death bus |newspaper=The Standard |location=Hong Kong |date=August 31, 2010 |accessdate=August 31, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721085554/http://paper.thestandard.com.hk/Default.htm?href=TheStandard%2F2010%2F08%2F31&pageno=3&view=document |archivedate=July 21, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> However, on September 3, 2010, De Lima admitted that the police might have accidentally shot some of the hostages.<ref>{{Cite news|author= the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/09/09/philippines.bus.hostage/index.html?hpt=T1#fbid=KI9W1Oknxyp |title=Philippines admits police may have shot some hostages in bus standoff - CNN.com |publisher=CNN |date=September 9, 2010 |accessdate=September 23, 2010}}</ref>
After the completion of the initial inquiry on September 15, 2010, the JIIRC traveled to Hong Kong to interview survivors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=13&art_id=102617&sid=29488518&con_type=1&d_str=20100906&sear_year=2010 |title=Philippine probe team to speak to survivors |work=The Standard |location=Hong Kong |date=September 6, 2010 |accessdate=September 23, 2010}}</ref> The report was delivered first to the Chinese embassy in Manila on September 20, 2010, before being released to the general public, in an attempt to "repair the nation’s relations with China".<ref name="ReportDelivery">{{Cite news|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/node/278068/12-ho|title=Hostage Report Urges Charges Against 15|publisher=The Manila Bulletin Newspaper|first=Genalyn|last=Kabiling|first2=Roy|last2=Mabasa|date=September 20, 2010|accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref>
The official report identified eight critical errors of the handling of the hostage crisis:<ref>Benitez, Mary Ann (September 21, 2010). [http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=103146&sid=29654392&con_type=1&d_str=20100921&sear_year=2010 "Eight deadly blunders"], ''The Standard'' (Hong Kong)</ref> * Manila Mayor Alfredo Lim failed to properly activate the crisis management committee, depriving the chief negotiator and others of critical information and operational intelligence. * The authorities were unable to appreciate Mendoza's demands, and there was a lack of communication with and involvement of the Department of Justice. * Gregorio Mendoza was allowed to join the negotiating team. * The side-issue of Gregorio Mendoza had been allowed to preoccupy Lim, Rodolfo Magtibay and Chief negotiator Orlando Yebra at a critical moment, setting off a chain of events that led to Mendoza becoming "fatally hostile". * Lim decided to arrest Gregorio Mendoza. * Lim and Magtibay were absent from the command post at a crucial time, having a meal, which created a decision-making vacuum. * "The inefficient, disorganised and stalled assault" took place without "vital information" about the bus. Magtibay rejected an order from the Philippine National Police director for Manila to use the national elite Special Action Force. * There was no plan for what to do after the assault and the crime scene was not preserved.
The report also recommended administrative or criminal charges for 15 individuals and organisations, including Manila mayor Alfredo Lim, vice-mayor [[Isko Moreno]], Ombudsmen [[Merceditas Gutierrez]] and Emilio Gonzales III, government undersecretary Rico J. Puno, retired Philippine National Police chief director general Jesus Verzosa, National Capital Region Police Office director Leocadio Santiago Jr., Manila Police District chief superintendent Rodolfo Magtibay, MPD hostage negotiator Orlando Yebra, SWAT commander Santiago Pascual, journalists [[Erwin Tulfo]] and Mike Rogas, and three broadcasting networks.<ref name="ReportDelivery" />
On March 31, 2011, Ombudsman Emilio Gonzales was dismissed by President Aquino for his "inordinate and unjustified delay" in handling Mendoza's appeal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=672155|title=Noy fires deputy Ombudsman|first=Delon|last=Porcalla|publisher=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=April 2, 2011|accessdate=April 19, 2011}}</ref> Gonzales was the first individual to receive direct sanction from the Philippine government in connection with the incident.<ref>{{zh-hk icon}} {{cite news|url=http://www.rthk.org.hk/rthk/news/expressnews/20110401/news_20110401_55_745399.htm|publisher=[[Radio Television Hong Kong|RTHK]]|date=April 1, 2011|accessdate=April 19, 2011|title=菲律賓首名官員因馬尼拉人質事件被撤職}}</ref> He appealed the decision, claiming that he was "prejudged guilty before the investigation started".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=675628|title=Deputy Ombudsman seeks TRO vs. Palace's dismissal order|publisher=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=April 12, 2011|accessdate=April 19, 2011}}</ref>
===Investigations by the Hong Kong government=== On August 25, 2010, the bodies of the victims were brought back to Hong Kong on a government-chartered flight.<ref name="home">{{cite news|title=Home|first=Natalie|last=Wong|date=August 26, 2010|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=102196&sid=29373108&con_type=1|accessdate=June 21, 2011}}</ref> The Coroner decided that an investigation into their deaths should be carried out, and ordered autopsies on all eight bodies. Five bodies were ultimately autopsied; the remaining three were not autopsied by requests from their families.<ref name=deathprobe>Lee, Colleen (August 27, 2010) [http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=102258&sid=29388320&con_type=1&d_str=20100827&sear_year=2010 "HK death probe begins"] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/68XFyXlLh?url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=102258&sid=29388320&con_type=1&d_str=20100827&sear_year=2010 |date=June 19, 2012 }}, ''The Standard''.</ref>
The Hong Kong Government invited 116 Philippine witnesses to participate in their investigation, which began on February 14, 2011.<ref name="HKProbeInvitation">{{Cite news|url=http://news.singtao.ca/toronto/2011-01-21/hongkong1295601584d2966420.html|title=港人質慘案聆訊 菲證人接傳票|publisher=[[Sing Tao Daily]] Canada version|location=Canada|date=January 21, 2011|accessdate=February 11, 2011}}{{zh-hk icon}}</ref> Among those invited were Gregorio Mendoza, the hostage-taker's brother, Manila mayor Alfredo Lim, Vice-Mayor Isko Moreno, reporters who covered the incident, members of the SWAT team and a number of forensic experts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/7943139-witnesses-invited-by-hk-for-manila-tourist-bus-probe |title=Witnesses invited by HK for Manilla Tourist Bus Probe |work=The Standard |location=Hong Kong |date=January 20, 2011 |accessdate=February 7, 2011}}</ref> Lim and Moreno rejected the invitation. They claimed that, rather than conduct another probe, Hong Kong should respect the conclusion of the Philippines' investigation that Mendoza was responsible for the deaths. They claimed that the Hong Kong probe was an encroachment of Philippine sovereignty and independence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90031975?Manila%20officials%20won%26%23146%3Bt%20attend%20Hong%20Kong%20bus%20hostage%20investigation |title=Manilla Officials won't attend Hong Kong Bus Investigation |work=The Standard |location=Hong Kong |date=January 25, 2011 |accessdate=February 6, 2011}}</ref>
The Hong Kong investigation interviewed 31 witnesses from Hong Kong and 10 from the Philippines.<ref name="bbc20110323" /> The coroner's five-member jury had to answer "yes", "no", or "uncertain" to a list of 44 statements, a method that was unique to Hong Kong's history and procedures.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=109463&sid=31773203&con_type=1&d_str=20110324&sear_year=2011#|title=Four deadly questions left unanswered|location=Hong Kong|publisher=The Standard|first=Natalie|last=Wong|date=March 24, 2011|accessdate=April 19, 2011}}</ref> The narrative verdict found that all eight victims were "unlawfully killed" and blamed the Philippine authorities' incompetent handling of the crisis as a direct cause of their deaths, although it declined to attribute any criminal or civil liability.<ref name="bbc20110323" />
===Compensation issue=== In August 2011, two survivors of the crisis, Joe Chan Kwok-chu (陳國柱) and Yik Siu-ling (易小玲), along with Tse Che-kin, brother of Masa Tse, met with Philippines government officials to discuss compensation. Chief executive Donald Tsang refused to intervene, labeling it a civil case.<ref>{{cite news|title=Manila hostage crisis survivors to seek compensation from PHL govt|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/229219/nation/manila-hostage-crisis-survivors-to-seek-compensation-from-phl-govt|accessdate=August 12, 2011|newspaper=GMANews.tv|date=August 12, 2011}}</ref> [[Democratic Party (Hong Kong)|Democratic Party]] lawmaker [[James To]] had assisted Chan and Yik in their plea for legal aid, which was expensive and complicated.<ref name=scmpcomp1>{{cite news|last=Cheung|first=Simpson|title=Call to push Philippines to pay up|newspaper=[[South China Morning Post]]|date=August 12, 2011}}</ref> During the visit by Manila Mayor Estrada and Cabinet Secretary Almendras to meet with the victims and Hong Kong officials, the latter had stated that a "token of solidarity" will be given to the victims and their families.<ref name="New">http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/focus/04/24/14/how-philippines-hong-kong-agreed-closure</ref> It, however, was not officially addressed as compensation money.<ref name="New"/>
In 2014, the Hong Kong government, Philippines government and victims’ families reached an agreement under which an undisclosed amount of compensation was paid by Manila to the victims' families. <ref>http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/2141503/duterte-apologises-hong-kong-victims-manila-hostage-tragedy</ref> <ref>http://www.scmp.com/comment/insight-opinion/article/1496243/no-winners-manila-bus-hostage-row-finally-ends</ref>
==Reactions==
===Chinese government=== Chinese foreign minister [[Yang Jiechi]] stated that he was "appalled" by the event,<ref name=bbcwarning>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11067310 |title=Hong Kong warns against Philippines travel after deaths|publisher=BBC News |date=August 24, 2010 |accessdate=August 24, 2010}}</ref> and sent a team to the Philippines to "deal with the situation".<ref name="bbcwarning"/> China's state-run ''[[Global Times]]'' called the Philippines "one of the most chaotic countries in Southeast Asia" following the shootings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.ibtimes.com/articles/45880/20100824/philippines-defends-handling-of-bus-hostage-crisis.htm |title=Philippines defends handling of bus hostage crisis|publisher=[[International Business Times]]|first1=John|last1=Mair|first2=Ben|last2=Blanchard|date=August 24, 2010 |accessdate=August 24, 2010}}</ref>
Additionally, the Chinese consul in the Philippines asked for a written statement of accountability from the Philippine government,<ref>{{cite web|script-title=zh:中方要求菲律宾书面解释救援行动 |url=http://news.sina.com.cn/c/2010-08-23/225320958959.shtml |accessdate=August 23, 2010 |work=[[Sina.com]] |date=August 23, 2010 |language=Chinese}}</ref> and rejected the explanation given by President [[Benigno Aquino III]] at an August 24, 2010 press conference.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.ifeng.com/hongkong/special/feilvbinjiechi/content-2/detail_2010_08/24/2223626_0.shtml |script-title=zh:中国驻菲领事王晓波：中国政府工作组已抵马尼拉 |work=ifeng.com |date=August 24, 2010 |accessdate=August 24, 2010 |language=Chinese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XGSsfoA?url=http://news.ifeng.com/hongkong/special/feilvbinjiechi/content-2/detail_2010_08/24/2223626_0.shtml |archivedate=June 19, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Plans for a delegation led by Philippine vice-president [[Jejomar Binay]] to visit Beijing and Hong Kong on August 26–27, 2010 to soothe tensions and "explain the hostage incident" was rejected by the Chinese government, pending the outcome of a complete investigation report.<ref>{{zh-hk icon}}{{Cite news|url=http://news.sina.com.hk/cgi-bin/nw/show.cgi/3/1/1/1834277/1.html |title= 真相未查清 京拒菲訪華 |work=Ming Pao |location=Hong Kong via [[Sina.com]] news |date=August 27, 2010 |accessdate=August 28, 2010}}</ref>
On August 27, 2010, the Chinese embassy in the Philippines expressed anger at the Mendoza family's decision to cover Mendoza's [[coffin]] with the [[Flag of the Philippines]] during his [[Wake (ceremony)|wake]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.163.com/10/0827/20/6F4EDJ3A000146BD.html |script-title=zh:中国驻菲大使馆谴责凶手棺木盖国旗 |work=[[NetEase]] |date=August 27, 2010 |accessdate=August 27, 2010 |language=Chinese}}</ref>
